THFM-AU-01.name: Authority Impersonation Susceptibility
THFM-AU-01.description: Compliance with requests from perceived authority figures (CEO, IT admin, law enforcement) without verification

exploitedBy.rationale: Impersonation of CEO, IT admin, or law enforcement to extract credentials or authorise transactions
Phishing emails framed as executive directives or IT security alerts bypass critical evaluation

THFM-AU-02.name: Organisational Hierarchy Compliance
THFM-AU-02.description: Following instructions from anyone perceived as senior, even outside normal chain of command

exploitedBy.rationale: Internal spearphishing from compromised senior accounts exploits hierarchical deference
Phishing for information framed as requests from senior staff bypasses verification instincts

THFM-AU-03.name: Technical Authority Deference
THFM-AU-03.description: Trusting requests that appear to come from IT, Security, or System Administrator roles

exploitedBy.rationale: Vishing calls impersonating IT helpdesk or security team exploit technical authority trust
Impersonation of IT staff to request credential resets or system access

THFM-UR-01.name: Time Pressure Response
THFM-UR-01.description: Making security decisions under artificial deadlines without proper verification

exploitedBy.rationale: Spearphishing links with account expiry or deadline framing bypass deliberate evaluation
User execution triggered by urgent-seeming requests that override security judgement

THFM-UR-02.name: Loss Aversion Response
THFM-UR-02.description: Taking risky action to avoid perceived loss (account lockout, data deletion, missed deadline)

exploitedBy.rationale: Phishing with payment overdue or account suspension framing exploits fear of loss
MFA fatigue attacks exploit loss aversion — users approve to stop repeated prompts disrupting work

THFM-UR-03.name: Fear-Based Compliance
THFM-UR-03.description: Complying with threatening messages (legal action, regulatory penalty, security incident)

exploitedBy.rationale: Phishing with legal threat or security compromise framing triggers fear-driven compliance
Phishing for information using regulatory or legal pretexts to extract sensitive data

THFM-TR-01.name: Internal Trust Exploitation
THFM-TR-01.description: Trusting communications from colleagues or known senders without verifying authenticity

exploitedBy.rationale: Internal spearphishing from compromised colleague accounts exploits established trust relationships
Compromised accounts of known contacts used to deliver malicious content via trusted channels

THFM-TR-02.name: Relationship-Based Compliance
THFM-TR-02.description: Granting requests from people with established rapport, bypassing normal verification procedures

exploitedBy.rationale: Trusted third-party relationships abused to bypass verification that would apply to unknown parties
Impersonation of known contacts leverages existing rapport to bypass security procedures

THFM-TR-03.name: Social Proof Compliance
THFM-TR-03.description: Following perceived group behaviour — assuming safety because colleagues also received or responded

exploitedBy.rationale: Mass phishing where colleagues also received the email creates false social proof of legitimacy
User execution driven by perception that others have already clicked or approved similar requests

THFM-TR-04.name: Reciprocity Obligation
THFM-TR-04.description: Feeling obligated to return a favour, even when the original favour was unrequested

exploitedBy.rationale: Pretexting with prior unrequested help creates reciprocity obligation to share information

THFM-CU-01.name: Curiosity-Driven Action
THFM-CU-01.description: Opening attachments or clicking links driven by curiosity about content

exploitedBy.rationale: Malicious links with intriguing subject lines exploit curiosity to drive clicks
Malicious files with interesting filenames or content previews trigger curiosity-driven execution
Spearphishing attachments with curiosity-baiting content bypass rational risk assessment

THFM-CU-02.name: Incentive-Driven Action
THFM-CU-02.description: Taking risky actions motivated by offered rewards (gift cards, prizes, bonuses)

exploitedBy.rationale: Spearphishing via social media or messaging services with reward offers exploits incentive motivation

THFM-CU-03.name: Information-Seeking Behaviour
THFM-CU-03.description: Pursuing interesting or sensitive information beyond need-to-know

exploitedBy.rationale: Phishing for information baited with interesting data exploits information-seeking drive

THFM-HB-01.name: Security Fatigue
THFM-HB-01.description: Habituation to security prompts leading to automatic approve responses

exploitedBy.rationale: MFA fatigue attacks exploit habituated approval responses to repeated security prompts
Routine approval of security dialogs and warnings due to prompt fatigue enables malicious execution

THFM-HB-02.name: Cognitive Load Exploitation
THFM-HB-02.description: Making poor security decisions under high workload or distraction

exploitedBy.rationale: Phishing timed to busy periods exploits reduced cognitive capacity for security evaluation
User execution of malicious content when cognitive load reduces ability to evaluate risk

THFM-HB-03.name: Automation Bias
THFM-HB-03.description: Over-trusting automated systems, AI recommendations, or verified badges

exploitedBy.rationale: Phishing that passes email gateway creates false confidence — if it got through filters it must be safe
Impersonation with verified-looking badges or certificates exploits trust in automated verification

THFM-HB-04.name: Routine Deviation Blindness
THFM-HB-04.description: Failure to notice anomalous requests when they resemble normal workflow

exploitedBy.rationale: Internal spearphishing that mimics normal email workflow exploits inattentional blindness to anomalies
Impersonation requests that closely match routine patterns bypass anomaly detection

THFM-IN-01.name: Financial Pressure
THFM-IN-01.description: Financial difficulties creating motivation for fraud or data theft for sale

THFM-IN-02.name: Organisational Disgruntlement
THFM-IN-02.description: Perceived unfairness, passed over for promotion, disciplinary conflict

THFM-IN-03.name: Ideological Motivation
THFM-IN-03.description: Political, religious, or ethical beliefs conflicting with organisational mission

THFM-IN-04.name: Coercion Vulnerability
THFM-IN-04.description: Susceptibility to blackmail, extortion, or external pressure

THFM-IN-05.name: Negligence Pattern
THFM-IN-05.description: Habitual disregard for security policies without malicious intent

THFM-IN-06.name: Privilege Accumulation
THFM-IN-06.description: Excessive access rights accumulated over tenure without periodic review

THFM-IN-07.name: Departure Risk
THFM-IN-07.description: Impending departure creating data theft window
